Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Microscopic (<100 um) imaging in centimeter-deep tissues based on an ultrasound-switchable fluorescence technique

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

#1253199
Yuan, Baohong

The PI proposes to conduct microscopic imaging in centimeter deep tissue. They have recently, for the first time, developed an ultrasound-switchable fluorescence (USF) technique that is fundamentally different from current imaging methods. In this project, they will develop a USF technique for deep tumor (~2-3 cm) microscopic imaging (<100 ìm). The technique will be evaluated and optimized in tissue phantoms, ex vivo tissue samples, and live animals. The research will also be locally and globally integrated with educations of students, high school teachers and the general public.

This USF technique will have high spatial resolution (<100 ìm, like high-frequency ultrasound), and relatively large imaging depth (~2-3 cm like low-frequency ultrasound. The proposed USF imaging technique can be potentially used to visualize microscopic structural, functional and molecular information of a small but centimeter deep tumor. It can greatly benefit many types of cancer imaging, such as breast or prostate cancer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An ultrasound-switchable fluorescence (USF) imaging technique has been successfully developed, which can image centimeter-deep tissue via fluorescence contrast with high-spatial resolution. The USF imaging was demonstrated and optimized in tissue phantoms in tissue-mimic phantoms, ex vivo tissue samples, and in vivo tissues. The imaging methods and systems were also used to educate students, teachers and general public. Compared with other imaging technologies, USF outstands due to the use of non-ionizing radiation, much low cost and providing optical fluorescence contrast with high spatial resolution in deep tissues. USF has great potentials to be used for both preclinical and clinical applications to benefit many types of cancer imaging, such as breast, prostate or other cancer. During the entire life of the award, the following outcomes have been achieved: (1) USF imaging contrast agents and systems have been successfully developed and characterized, (2) high-resolution USF imaging in centimeter-deep tissue has been achieved, characterized and optimized in tissue phantoms, ex vivo tissue samples and in vivo tissues, (3) two related courses for both undergraduate and graduate students have been developed, offered and improved, and (4) the imaging systems have been used to educate students, teachers and general public.The specific achievements include: (1) peer-reviewed journal publications and conference abstracts/posters/presentations; (2) PhD dissertations; (3) US/International patent applications; (4) courses for both undergraduate and graduate students.
